newsitem.title: POLAND: Iraq attack may delay Polish fuel price easing - PM.
newsitem.headline: Iraq attack may delay Polish fuel price easing - PM.

text.p: The U.S. missile strikes against Iraq and the ensuing worldwide oil price rally may delay liberalisation of fuel prices in Poland, Prime Minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz said on Wednesday.

"The liberalisation of fuels prices in the context of growing world prices would not be advantagous, because it would lead to increases on the domestic market," Cimoszewicz said in remarks broadcast by private Radio Zet.
"Therefore we must now even more carefully consider the date of fuels price liberalisation," he told reporters.
The government had earlier said it wanted to liberalise fuel prices, now set by the finance minister, in autumn this year as part of its programme to restructure and modernise its oil sector.
High crude oil prices and domestic caps on petrol prices, designed to curb inflation, have hit Polish oil firms which find production increasingly less profitable.
The government has introduced a 300,000 tonne duty-free quota for fuel imports to offset predicted shortages of petrol.
It plans another quota of the same size later this year.
